intro: Anacyclus pedunculatus, commonly known as the Persian buttercup, is a flowering plant native to regions of southern Europe, North Africa, and western Asia. It belongs to the family Asteraceae and is characterized by its yellow, dandelion-like flowers and basal rosette of leaves. The plant typically grows in dry, sunny habitats and has hairy stems and leaves. Its flowers are hermaphroditic, meaning they contain both male and female reproductive organs. Anacyclus pedunculatus is often used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory and analgesic properties.
